ing devices designed for the speedy and efficient handling of traffic and the
safe collection and recording of all tolls paid by the traveling public. The
toll plaza layout for the Sandy Point-Kent Island site is shown on “Gen-
eral Plan and Elevation,” Plate 68.

GENERAL AND ADMINISTRATIVE EXPENSE FOR MAINTAINING AND OPERATING
THE BRIDGES

Coverdale and Colpitts, Consulting Engineers, New York City, have
estimated the general and administrative expense for maintaining and
operating bridge combinations as tabulated above. This tabulation,
Table 61, is herein reproduced for the purpose of ready reference.

MAINTENANCE, OPERATION, AND INSURANCE

Coverdale and Colpitts have also estimated the operating expenses for
each of the crossings in the program, and the tabulation of such expenses
for the operation, maintenance and insurance requirements for the proposed
Chesapeake Bay Crossings are herein tabulated for ready reference in
Table 62.

TRAFFIC REPORT

Coverdale and Colpitts, Consulting Engineers, New York City, under
date of September 3, 1938 have reported to the State Roads Commission on
estimated traffic, gross revenues, and toll schedules for the crossings included
in the State of Maryland’s Primary Bridge Program. The estimates in
this report show that a bridge at the Sandy Point-Kent Island Site may
be expected to produce $113,000 more gross revenue than a bridge at the
Millers Island-Tolchester Site, if each crossing be considered as an inde-
pendent unit on the assumption that none of the other crossings is con-
structed. The gross revenues have been estimated on the basis of a toll
rate of $1.00 per passenger car and twenty cents for each extra passenger,
with bus and truck rates as set forth in detail in the report and as herein
listed for convenient reference in Table 63.

The estimates of number of vehicles and gross revenues for the first five
years of operation and the average of the first five years are tabulated in
Table 64 for both the Millers Island-Tolchester and Sandy Point-Kent
Island Sites.

The traffic engineers have estimated that a bridge at the Sandy Point-
